Here's the result of running `cat -n` on /tmp/tmpkelcrhj5/astropy/README.rst:
     1	=======
     2	Astropy
     3	=======
     4	
     5	.. container::
     6	
     7	    |Actions Status| |CircleCI Status| |Coverage Status| |PyPI Status| |Documentation Status| |Pre-Commit| |isort Status| |black| |Zenodo|
     8	
     9	The Astropy Project (http://astropy.org/) is a community effort to develop a
    10	single core package for Astronomy in Python and foster interoperability between
    11	Python astronomy packages. This repository contains the core package which is
    12	intended to contain much of the core functionality and some common tools needed
    13	for performing astronomy and astrophysics with Python.
    14	
    15	Releases are `registered on PyPI <https://pypi.org/project/astropy>`_,
    16	and development is occurring at the
    17	`project's GitHub page <http://github.com/astropy/astropy>`_.
    18	
    19	For installation instructions, see the `online documentation <https://docs.astropy.org/>`_
    20	or  `docs/install.rst <docs/install.rst>`_ in this source distribution.
    21	
    22	Contributing Code, Documentation, or Feedback
    23	---------------------------------------------
    24	
    25	The Astropy Project is made both by and for its users, so we welcome and
    26	encourage contributions of many kinds. Our goal is to keep this a positive,
    27	inclusive, successful, and growing community by abiding with the
    28	`Astropy Community Code of Conduct <http://www.astropy.org/about.html#codeofconduct>`_.
    29	
    30	More detailed information on contributing to the project or submitting feedback
    31	can be found on the `contributions <http://www.astropy.org/contribute.html>`_
    32	page. A `summary of contribution guidelines <CONTRIBUTING.md>`_ can also be
    33	used as a quick reference when you are ready to start writing or validating
    34	code for submission.
    35	
    36	Getting started with GitHub Codespaces
    37	--------------------------------------
    38	
    39	Codespaces is a cloud development environment supported by GitHub. None of the Astropy build machinery depends on it, but it is a convenient way to quickly get started doing development on Astropy.
    40	
    41	To get started, create a codespace for this repository by clicking this 👇
    42	
    43	|Codespaces|
    44	
    45	A codespace will open in a web-based version of Visual Studio Code. The `dev container <.devcontainer/devcontainer.json>`_ is fully configured with software needed for this project. Feel free to take a look at `GitHub Codespaces Support <https://support.github.com/features/codespaces>`_ page for help.
    46	
    47	**Note**: Dev containers is an open spec which is supported by `GitHub Codespaces <https://github.com/codespaces>`_ and `other tools <https://containers.dev/supporting>`_.
    48	
    49	Supporting the Project
    50	----------------------
    51	
    52	|NumFOCUS| |Donate|
    53	
    54	The Astropy Project is sponsored by NumFOCUS, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit in the
    55	United States. You can donate to the project by using the link above, and this
    56	donation will support our mission to promote sustainable, high-level code base
    57	for the astronomy community, open code development, educational materials, and
    58	reproducible scientific research.
    59	
    60	License
    61	-------
    62	
    63	Astropy is licensed under a 3-clause BSD style license - see the
    64	`LICENSE.rst <LICENSE.rst>`_ file.
    65

   113	If you locally cloned this repo before 7 Apr 2021
   114	-------------------------------------------------
   115	
   116	The primary branch for this repo has been transitioned from ``master`` to
   117	``main``.  If you have a local clone of this repository and want to keep your
   118	local branch in sync with this repo, you'll need to do the following in your
   119	local clone from your terminal::
   120	
   121	   git fetch --all --prune
   122	   # you can stop here if you don't use your local "master"/"main" branch
   123	   git branch -m master main
   124	   git branch -u origin/main main
   125	
   126	If you are using a GUI to manage your repos you'll have to find the equivalent
   127	commands as it's different for different programs. Alternatively, you can just
   128	delete your local clone and re-clone!
   129
